anchor.surface_text: For the reasons expressed we hold that the petitioner has been unable to make out a case for the grant of a writ u

Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of fundamental rights. C. Chatterjee, K. B. Roastagi, L. M. Singhvi and S. Balakrishnan, for the petitioner. B. Agarwala, G. C. Kasliwal, Advocate-General, Rajasthan, Indu Soni and K. Baldev Mehta, for respondent No. 1. S. Bindra, A. S. Nambiar and R. N. Sachthey, for respondent No. 2. Baldev Mehta and Indu Soni, for respondents Nos. 3 and 4. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Ramaswami, J.-The petitioner, Sri Sant Ram Sharma has obtained a rule from this Court calling upon the respondents to show cause why a writ under Art. 32 of the Constitution should number be granted for quashing two orders of the State of Rajasthan, one dated March 22, 1966 whereby Sri Hanuman Sharma, respondent No. 3 was promoted as Inspector General of Police, Rajasthan superseding the petitioner, and the other dated April 28, 1966 promoting Sri Sultan Singh, respondent No. 4 as Additional Inspector General of Police superseding the petitioner.

The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Ramaswami, J.-The petitioner, Sri Sant Ram Sharma has obtained a rule from this Court calling upon the respondents to show cause why a writ under Art. 32 of the Constitution should number be granted for quashing two orders of the State of Rajasthan, one dated March 22, 1966 whereby Sri Hanuman Sharma, respondent No. 3 was promoted as Inspector General of Police, Rajasthan superseding the petitioner, and the other dated April 28, 1966 promoting Sri Sultan Singh, respondent No. 4 as Additional Inspector General of Police superseding the petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: On September 8, 1954 by a numberification of the Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India, the Indian Police Service  Regulation of Seniority  Rules, 1954 came into force. Rule 6 of the said Rules required that a Gradation List of all Police Officers in the State should be maintained to ascertain their respective seniority.

issues.text: whether the petitioner was entitled, as of right, to be promoted as Deputy Inspector General of Police in 1955 or as Inspector General of Police in 1966 merely on the ground that his name stood first in the Gradation List prepared under Rule 6 of the Indian Police Service Regulation of Seniority Rules, 1954

anchor.surface_text: The question for determination in this case is whether the petitioner was entitled, as of right, to be promoted as Deputy Inspector General of Police in 1955 or as Inspector General of Police in 1966 merely on the ground that his name stood first in the Gradation List prepared under Rule 6 of the Indian Police Service Regulation of Seniority Rules, 1954.

issues.text: whether the posts of Deputy Inspector General of Police, Additional Inspector General of Police and Inspector General of Police in Rajasthan State are selection posts and outside the junior and senior time-scales of pay

anchor.surface_text: it is apparent from a perusal of Rules 3 and 8 of the Indian Police Service Pay Rules, 1954 read with Part B of Sch. III of those Rules that the posts of Deputy Inspector General of Police, Additional Inspector General of Police and Inspector General of Police in Rajasthan State are selection posts and outside the junior and senior time- scales of pay.

issues.text: whether in the absence of any statutory rules governing promotions to selection grade posts the Government can issue administrative instructions regarding the principle to be followed in promotions

anchor.surface_text: We proceed to consider the next contention of Mr. N.C. Chatterjee that in the absence of any statutory rules governing promotions to selection grade posts the Government cannot issue administrative instructions and such administrative instructions cannot impose any restrictions not found in the Rules already framed.

issues.text: whether the fundamental rights of the petitioner under Arts. 14 and 16 of the Constitution have been violated by the promotion orders

anchor.surface_text: It was therefore said that the fundamental rights of the petitioner under Arts. 14 and 16 have been violated and the orders of the State of Rajasthan dated March 22, 1966 and April 28, 1966 should be quashed by the grant of a writ in the nature of certiorari with a direction to the 1st respondent to consider the petitioners claim N1sC1-9 afresh for being promoted to the post of Inspector General of Police.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Determined by perusal of Rules 3 and 8 of IPS Pay Rules 1954 read with Part B Sch. III classifying them as selection grade posts carrying pay above time-scale.

holdings.text: The ranking or position in the Gradation List does not confer any right to be promoted to selection posts and promotion to selection grades or selection posts is to be based primarily on merit and not on seniority alone.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the respondents are right in their contention that the ranking or position in the Gradation L

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-established rule supported by government communications and administrative practice; seniority considered only when merits equal.

holdings.text: If the rules are silent on any particular point Government can fill up the gaps and supplement the rules and issue instructions not inconsistent with the rules already framed.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that Government cannot amend or supersede statutory rules by administrative instructions, but if the rules are silent on any particular point Government can fill up the gaps and supplement the rules and issue instructions not inconsistent with the rules already framed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Executive power under Arts. 309, 162 allows supplementation of silent rules; supported by precedents like B.N. Nagarajan v. State of Mysore.

holdings.text: The petitioner is unable to substantiate that there was no consideration of his case at the time of promotion of respondents 3 and 4; the State considered the case, record, experience and merit of the petitioner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Objective consideration on merit for selection posts; no arbitrariness as case considered with others.

holdings.text: Promotion to selection grade posts based on merit with seniority only when merits equal does not violate Arts. 14 and 16.

anchor.surface_text: As a matter of long administrative practice promotion to selection grade posts in the Indian Police Service has been based on merit and seniority has been taken into consideration only when merit of the candidates is otherwise equal and we are unable to accept the argument

holdings.reasoning_summary: Balances public interest in efficiency with equality; long administrative practice; rejects nepotism argument as merit protects against it.

holdings.text: The petitioner has been unable to make out a case for the grant of a writ under Art. 32 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petition fails on all grounds: no right from seniority, case considered, no Art 14/16 violation.

precedents.citation: P. C. Wadhwa v. Union of India. 1

anchor.surface_text: P. C. Wadhwa v. Union of India. 1 But the ratio of that case has numberbearing on the question presented for determination in the present case. The question involved in that case was whether under the relevant rules governing the Indian Police Service, a member thereof was entitled as of right to be promoted to a post in the senior scale as and when a vacancy  except a vacancy in the promotion quota  arose therein and numberone senior to him was available for that post.

precedents.case_name: P. C. Wadhwa v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: member of Indian Police Service entitled as of right to promotion to senior scale post when vacancy available and no senior available
precedents.cited_holding: a person in the junior time-scale of the service is as much a cadre officer as one holding a post in the senior time-scale or a post above the timescale and had a right to hold a post on the senior scale of pay subject to availability and seniority; does not extend to posts above time-scale

precedents.citation: P. C. Wadhwa v. Union of India 1

anchor.surface_text: The decision of this Court in P. C. Wadhwa v. Union of India 1  is therefore of numberassistance to the petitioner and for the reasons we have already given, we are of the opinion that the three posts of Inspector General of Police, Additional Inspector General of Police and Deputy Inspector General of Police in Rajasthan State are selection posts and outside the junior or senior time-scales of pay.

precedents.case_name: P. C. Wadhwa v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: decision on right to promotion to senior scale does not assist claim for selection posts

precedents.citation: B. N. Nagarajan v. State of Mysore, 1

anchor.surface_text: In B. N. Nagarajan v. State of Mysore, 1  it was pointed out by this Court that it is number obligatory under the proviso to Art. 309 of the Constitution to make rules of recruitment, etc., before a service can be companystituted or a post created or filled, and, secondly, the State Government has executive power, in relation to all matters with respect to which the Legislature of the State has power, to make laws.

precedents.case_name: B. N. Nagarajan v. State of Mysore
precedents.cited_proposition: not obligatory to make rules under Art. 309 proviso before constituting service or filling post; State has executive power to act without rules
precedents.cited_holding: State Government has executive power in respect of State Public Services and nothing in Art. 309 abridges executive power under Art. 162 without a law

precedents.citation: T. Cajee v. U. Jormanik Siem 1

anchor.surface_text: A similar view  1 1966 3 S.C.R. 682. was taken by this Court in T. Cajee v. U. Jormanik Siem 1  where Wanchoo, J., as he then was, who delivered judgment on behalf of the majority, observed as follows at pp. 762-764 of the Report The High Court has taken the view that the appointment and succession of a Siem was number an administrative function of the District Council and that the District Council companyld only act by making a law with the assent of the Governor so far as the appointment and removal of a Siem was companycerned.

precedents.case_name: T. Cajee v. U. Jormanik Siem
precedents.cited_proposition: executive power to appoint and remove without prior legislative act or rules; legislative list does not preclude administrative action
precedents.cited_holding: power of appointment falls within administration and power of removal follows; no need for prior law or regulation for administrative personnel appointments
